{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":2973827,"name":"astrayelmgod","username":"astrayelmgod","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/a/858c86/{size}.png","created_at":"2021-10-28T15:28:31.017Z","cooked":"

We have a drawer full of modules that stopped working for no apparent reason. I don‚Äôt see any tools to diagnose them. Am I missing something, or are we the only ones losing modules? At the Tidal Tumble off-season event, we ended up changing out two PCMs, one VRM, and a motor controller. In the weeks leading up to that, we changed out two Robo_RIOS, one PDP, another PCM, and a couple more motor controllers.

In addition to testing the removed modules, the number of modules suggests we have some systemic problem somewhere. Power distribution? Surges back through the power supply when a motor shuts off? This robot was recently rewired by a student who wanted to minimize the CANbus wire complexity. He accomplished that at the expense of much longer motor wiring. I‚Äôm wondering if the longer wires created problems in the power distribution.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2021-10-28T15:28:31.017Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":10,"reads":364,"readers_count":363,"score":147.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":396887,"topic_slug":"what-to-do-with-failed-modules","display_username":"astrayelmgod","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":25945,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/what-to-do-with-failed-modules/396887/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":2973859,"name":"Matt Golman","username":"BordomBeThyName","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bordombethyname/{size}/147649_2.png","created_at":"2021-10-28T17:11:00.876Z","cooked":"

I‚Äôd also love to see procedures to test suspect components. We‚Äôve collected a ton of parts with ‚Äúbad?‚Äù written on them over the years, and it would be great to be able to either toss them or return them to circulation. We have PDPs, PCMs, VRMs, and Spark Maxes.

Does anyone out there have test plans developed for this stuff?

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2021-10-28T17:11:25.578Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":342,"readers_count":341,"score":113.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":396887,"topic_slug":"what-to-do-with-failed-modules","display_username":"Matt Golman","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":9246,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Retired üå¥"},"post_url":"/t/what-to-do-with-failed-modules/396887/2","custom_user_title":"Retired üå¥","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2973860,"name":"Carlos Gross Jones","username":"CarlosGJ","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/carlosgj/{size}/131747_2.png","created_at":"2021-10-28T17:17:13.298Z","cooked":"

The VRM is a dumb module, and you should be able to test that it meets spec with a power supply and DC programmable load (or possibly a selection of resistors): set the input voltage to nominal, apply the spec‚Äôd max and min loads to the outputs, look at the input and output voltage and current. Repeat at the spec‚Äôd max and min input voltages. Maybe apply load transients and look at the line and load regulation, if you‚Äôre feeling fancy.

All the other components are smart, and would require specialized (non-public) knowledge of the firmware to really develop good test procedures.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2021-10-28T17:17:13.298Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":324,"readers_count":323,"score":119.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":396887,"topic_slug":"what-to-do-with-failed-modules","display_username":"Carlos Gross Jones","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":9246,"username":"BordomBeThyName","name":"Matt Golman","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bordombethyname/{size}/147649_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":16115,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mere hours of work can save you entire minutes of planning"},"post_url":"/t/what-to-do-with-failed-modules/396887/3","custom_user_title":"Mere hours of work can save you entire minutes of planning","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2973880,"name":"Chris Herzog","username":"zog","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/zog/{size}/266762_2.png","created_at":"2021-10-28T18:17:15.496Z","cooked":"

A PCM is fairly user testable as the inputs and outputs are pretty simple and direct. Pressure switch input is basically on/off driving the compressor output and the solenoid outputs are also pretty straight forward.

Writing a test program would be a nice software team project. Drive the solenoid outputs from the code based on controller buttons and watch the LEDs for a quick check and drive an actual soleniod for the next test pass to check out the drivers while you probably could test the compressor output pretty well with a piece of wire on the input and an actual compressor hanging on the output (with the on-board LED being a good first check).

I‚Äôve always gotten frustrated by things pulled and labeled ‚ÄúBAD‚Äù or ‚ÄúBAD?‚Äù or ‚ÄúNot working‚Äù or whatever; there usually are no notes or anything indicating what the problem(s) were so it‚Äôs a real challenge to figure out where to go when you grab it off the shelf so I‚Äôm empathetic (we all are I‚Äôm betting).

I consider it a big win to just get people to take obviously fried and smoked motors and toss them into the scrap pile rather than putting them unlabeled on the shelf with the other motors for someone else to use‚Ä¶

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2021-10-28T18:17:15.496Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":2,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":276,"readers_count":275,"score":115.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":396887,"topic_slug":"what-to-do-with-failed-modules","display_username":"Chris Herzog","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":9246,"username":"BordomBeThyName","name":"Matt Golman","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/bordombethyname/{size}/147649_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":40142,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Doin' robot stuff... [ FRC 2151 + 3061 | Ri3D Redux '23 | RIP 4292 & 4241 ]"},"post_url":"/t/what-to-do-with-failed-modules/396887/4","custom_user_title":"Doin' robot stuff... [ FRC 2151 + 3061 | Ri3D Redux '23 | RIP 4292 & 4241 ]","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2973881,"name":"Allen Nuttle","username":"nuttle","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nuttle/{size}/124105_2.png","created_at":"2021-10-28T18:17:19.630Z","cooked":"

This many ‚Äúfailed‚Äù components really does suggest maybe there‚Äôs something else going on. If nothing else, keep a careful log of why something was swapped and what difference it made. Possible explanations range from the placebo effect to really bad luck, but testing the suspect parts would certainly help to make things more clear. If you have a bench top electrical/programming setup, you could use that to try out the questionable parts, one at a time, under more controlled conditions. If not, you could use these parts to create one and see how things go using that.

How‚Äôs your wiring? Replacing something has the obvious side effect of redoing the connections, so that‚Äôs something to consider. Another thing to try ‚Äì take all the suspect parts and turn them over while holding them over something to collect anything that falls out. Shake them, tap them, twist and turn them and see if you find metal shavings. If you do, that‚Äôs a red flag, as these can cause problems. Think about how you decide to replace things and if you might be able to learn more before taking this step. If this happens at an event, have a CSA take a good look at things. Also, asking another team that has solid electrical systems for advice is no bad thing.

I‚Äôm a big fan of writing explicit test mode code to help validate things on the robot. If you haven‚Äôt tried this, it can save a whole lot of time troubleshooting.

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2021-10-28T18:19:16.172Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":240,"readers_count":239,"score":68.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":396887,"topic_slug":"what-to-do-with-failed-modules","display_username":"Allen Nuttle","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":14283,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/what-to-do-with-failed-modules/396887/5","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2973885,"name":"Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)","username":"ngreen","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/ngreen/{size}/264478_2.png","created_at":"2021-10-28T18:26:05.121Z","cooked":"

Bad on some radios just meant the dc barrel connector spring was bent. But I guess if you only did poe they could be okay‚Ä¶but they still don‚Äôt usually make it on new robots.

For PCM and VRM having ports that don‚Äôt hold a wire or ferrule well might get designated bad.

Often when you have the parts you just move on to something that you know is new and doesn‚Äôt have wear that might cause unexpected failures. But the bad designation isn‚Äôt tested or maybe some maintenance could revive the part.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2021-10-28T18:26:05.121Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":214,"readers_count":213,"score":47.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":396887,"topic_slug":"what-to-do-with-failed-modules","display_username":"Nelson Green (1108 Mentor Coach Electrical Programming)","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":40142,"username":"zog","name":"Chris Herzog","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/zog/{size}/266762_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":2695,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/what-to-do-with-failed-modules/396887/6","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2973886,"name":"Brian Wagg","username":"cad321","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/c/c57346/{size}.png","created_at":"2021-10-28T18:37:24.455Z","cooked":"

For the Robo-RIO‚Äôs you mentioned being out of serivce, I highly recommend you reach out to National Instruments for support. They know that product better than anyone, and can certainly help get them going again.

A couple years back now, my highschool team managed to brick one of their RIO‚Äôs. After a few emails with NI confirming that the unit was indeed bricked, they had us ship the old unit back to them and they sent a replacement free of charge.

Similar suggestion for the Spark Max‚Äôs. REV has been great in the past with regards to troubleshooting their products. They‚Äôre also quite eager I‚Äôve found to hear from teams about the various ways their products have failed ‚Äúin the field.‚Äù Presumably to help them with future revisions and product development

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2021-10-28T18:37:24.455Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":211,"readers_count":210,"score":67.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":396887,"topic_slug":"what-to-do-with-failed-modules","display_username":"Brian Wagg","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":19532,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Brian Wagg"},"post_url":"/t/what-to-do-with-failed-modules/396887/7","custom_user_title":"Brian Wagg","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2973887,"name":"Andrew Lawrence","username":"Andrew_L","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/andrew_l/{size}/270442_2.png","created_at":"2021-10-28T18:39:14.479Z","cooked":"

Normally my go-to suggestion if something doesn‚Äôt seem to be working is to contact the supplier, but I‚Äôm gonna go out on a limb here and tag @Andy_Baker, @Jon_Jack, @R.C, @Greg_Needel, and @Mike_Copioli and ask what they all recommend teams do when they run into potentially ‚Äúfailed‚Äù components, and what the preferred plan of action is (send them back to company for inspection? Toss them?) so you can hear it straight from the horses‚Äô mouths.

A huge second here.

Working with the vendors is a way better solution than creating a museum of questionable parts.

They really want to help us.

In one year you‚Äôve seen more failures than our team has seen in 10. Did your well-meaning student get the battery polarity reversed at some point?

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2021-10-28T22:52:06.861Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":170,"readers_count":169,"score":79.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":396887,"topic_slug":"what-to-do-with-failed-modules","display_username":"Ken Pontbriant","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":17612,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC 230 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/what-to-do-with-failed-modules/396887/10","custom_user_title":"FRC 230 Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"-1","type":"emoji","count":2},{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2973943,"name":"JamesCH95","username":"JamesCH95","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jamesch95/{size}/1200_2.png","created_at":"2021-10-28T23:09:41.604Z","cooked":"

That or ESD‚Ä¶ It seems like something systemic.

True as far as it goes, but we‚Äôd also need CAN code, and our programming team is pretty overwhelmed, to put it nicely, We haven‚Äôt had a programming mentor in several years, and it shows.

","post_number":14,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2021-10-29T15:52:28.797Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":139,"readers_count":138,"score":32.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":396887,"topic_slug":"what-to-do-with-failed-modules","display_username":"astrayelmgod","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":17612,"username":"electroken","name":"Ken Pontbriant","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/electroken/{size}/160387_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":25945,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/what-to-do-with-failed-modules/396887/14","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2974075,"name":"Ken Pontbriant","username":"electroken","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/electroken/{size}/160387_2.png","created_at":"2021-10-29T18:11:49.003Z","cooked":"

The few FRC electronics I‚Äôve been inside have been very lightly protected for things like transient voltages, over voltages, and reverse polarity. That‚Äôs not a criticism, just a likely trade off to achieve a reasonable price with fairly low volume products.

I‚Äôm trying to remember what electrical failures we‚Äôve seen since the introduction of the roboRIO. Before that time we did have a digital sidecar and a few Jaguars go boom.

Since 2015:
Victor SP (2), known to have had power applied to the outputs with CIMs connected to the inputs.
roboRIO (1), would run existing code but would not accept new code. NI swapped this one with a refurbished one for free.
Falcon 500 (1), stone dead, reason unknown. The 2020 season ended about 10 minutes later and we never got to evaluating it.

The PDPs, VRMs, and PCMs have survived their times with us so far.

We‚Äôve also stunk up the occasional gymnasium with the aroma of flash-fried 550s and 775s.

","post_number":15,"post_type":1,"posts_count":21,"updated_at":"2021-10-29T18:16:24.415Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":2,"reads":125,"readers_count":124,"score":35.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":396887,"topic_slug":"what-to-do-with-failed-modules","display_username":"Ken Pontbriant","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":17612,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC 230 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/what-to-do-with-failed-modules/396887/15","custom_user_title":"FRC 230 Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":2974076,"name":"Matt Spradley","username":"mspradley","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mspradley/{size}/12218_2.png","created_at":"2021-10-29T18:21:24.035Z","cooked":"

Are you sure it wasn‚Äôt just a CAN bus issue? If the CAN bus isn‚Äôt routed in with a single line terminated on both ends with 120 ohms it can be pretty intermittant. This would include if the CAN bus was laid out in a hub and spoke pattern or there are long stubs.

All of the FRC modules have been pretty bulletproof for us. It was almost always a CAN bus issue when we thought it was a module. One time we replaced a PDU thinking it was bad and it turned out the CAN connection to the PDU was the issue.

You can look at the logs in the driver station and it will show CAN issues. Also, the lights on the modules usually indicate when it‚Äôs a CAN issue. They aren‚Äôt always right though. In the PDU example above, our PDU was flashing a light sequence that indicated it was bad. We replaced the PDU but noticed the CAN connection was iffy on the original connection. The replaced PDU worked, but the old one did as well on our other robot. We looked at the logs after the fact there we tons of CAN buffer overrun messages in the log that pointed to it being a CAN issue all along.

Cant find a pic right now. But our breaks were rare since we adapted our custom breakout boards

Here is the schematics and the pc board
PCB_PCB-6.0-drawingguyFINALSUCCESS_20190501161412.pdf (9.8 KB)

you can mount them side by side and make exchanging easy. On the PDP we have little pigtails on xt60 femal connectors the talons on the board have on the voltage input side xt60 males on the motor side xt60 female and all the motors terminate into xt60 males. So IOW everywhere where there is a power source (like in RL on a wall outlet) you have a female - something to plug into. so that makes it not possible to connect the motor side to the PDP. Also after putting the connectors on they stay on so a QC needs only to be done once that the connectors are on properly (which is usually done by me or another qualified adult to check for proper connector, proper solder, heat shrink etc etc. The breakout boards use .100 spacing connectors usually (except emergency) of the locking and where necessary polarizing nature (for example limit switches do not necessarily need polarized connectors.

This also makes testing easy as you can hook up the potentially bad module by itself into a test rig of the spare robo rio, PDP with a working motor. After making a preliminary test. The output of the Talon should show a voltage. On a neo you need a scope but we have a usb one that connects to the laptop. So its small portable and inexpensive enough and does the job I alos got one that is stand alone and about the size of a multimeter which I got for less than $100.

Assuming there is no blatant error message ‚Ä¶ (either LED or on the log)

So if you are sure the wiring is ok which we usually are. First thing is check the motor and the wire to the motor. To do that we have a spare motor with the proper plugs which we plug into the controller and then if the motor turns one way or the other then the controller likely is fine (you still could have a 2nd order breakdown that is one that only manifests itself under prolonged load.

Then after checking for mechanical obstruction you can connect the motor to a battery which is easy as it has a connector and you can make a setup with a connector for that test too.

The above should give some quick indications. IF the motor runs fine on the battery and a no load does not run then its either the power source (which would have been already detected as nothing lights up like if a fuse blew or some wire came loose somewhere. Or a can or controller problem. As our system is plug and play we at a competition switch the breakout/talon board out and then test it further. Like connection problems, broken solder joint etc. In one case in the past 5 years the talon actually wound up to be bad/damaged.

We only currently own 2 Neos so we have no real experience with them but I have worked with brushless motors and controllers before (non FRC projects).

Hope the above gives some kind of help and direction
